description.narrative: Core funding support to HelpAge International for the implementation of their 2015-2020 strategy. HelpAge operates in 62 low- and middle income countries in order to improve the living condition for people over 60 years old. The support is based on the rights-, health - as well as the poverty perspective. The global development of older peoples rights and safety net is the main focus.

Kärnstöd till HelpAge International för implementering av deras strategi 2015-2020. HelpAge International är ett sekretariat (inkl. HK-London, sju regionala kontor och 14 landkontor) för ett hundratal medlemsorganisationer (Affiliates) runt om i världen. HelpAge International är den enda globala organisationen som arbetar specifikt med äldre människors rättigheter som rätten till hälsovård, sociala trygghetssystem samt rätten att leva ett värdigt liv utan våld. Sidas stöd kommer bidra till genomförandet av HelpAges strategi för perioden 2015-2018. HelpAges strategiska mål är en värld där äldre kvinnor och män kan säga: 1) jag har den inkomst jag behöver; 2) jag får den bästa möjliga vård jag behöver; 3) jag är trygg, fri från all diskriminering och våld; samt 4) min röst är hörd.

The 2015-2020 strategy contains a series of outcomes under the four areas below. In 2018, gender and disability under inclusion have been added to the results framework as areas of particular focus.1. I have the income I need i. More older people will have access to adequate, sustainable minimum pensions as part of a social protection floorii. More households containing older people will be able to maintain, adapt or increase their income and food security2. I enjoy the best possible health and care, well being and dignity i. More older people will report better health, and well-being and more older people living in isolation, or with chronic conditions and frailty, will be supported to live well in a place of their choice.ii. More older people will be supported to prepare for and withstand the impact of shocks in their lives, livelihoods and health3. I am safe and secure, free from all forms of discrimination, violence and abuse i. Older people will have significantly better access to legal and other support services relating to violence and abuseii. More older people will be supported to prepare for and withstand the impact of shocks in their lives, livelihoods and health4. My voice is heard i. More older people will be able to participate in decision-making processes that will improve life in old age now and in the futureii. Significant progress will be made towards a convention on the rights of older peopleiii. The UN, governments, donors and other bodies will adopt age-inclusive policies and programmes, responding to the commitments of the post-2015 Sustainable Development Goals and of international humanitarian law 5. Inclusion: Gender and Disability i. Influencing on gender and ageingii. Collecting data that includes everyoneiii. Influencing on ageing and disabilityiv. Strengthening gender and disability inclusion

description.narrative: Examples of results until 2018: - Between 2014 and 2018, over 5 million additional older people supported by HelpAge on social protection across 12 countries received a pension for the first time in their lives. - HelpAge supported WHO’s work on ageing and health, including through the development of a joint work-plan based on the Global Strategy and Action Plan on Ageing and Health - National research and advocacy at country level achieved legislative, policy and practical changes to protect older people’s rights to freedom from violence, abuse and neglect in Moldova, Tanzania, South Africa and SriLanka - The UN adopted age-inclusive Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) Some of the results 2019/20 achieved: 1. I have the income I need- 1.28 million older people in six countries received a social pension for the first time.- £4.88 billion+ was paid to older people in the 18 countries where HelpAge has actively worked on social pensions over the past five years, representing a year-on-year increase of £202 million.- 38,000 older people (63 per cent women) across nine countries had their financial and food security protected and supported through our humanitarian and disaster risk reduction programmes.2. I enjoy the best possible health and care, well being and dignity- 225,784 older people in 17 countries received better health and care services or support as a result of HelpAge’s work – the majority of whom were older women (62 per cent).- 3.1 million older people benefited from new or revised government health and care policies.- 51,500 older people (63 per cent women) in 11 countries had their health, care and nutrition requirements provided for and protected during humanitarian crises, through emergency responses and disaster risk reduction.3. I am safe and secure, free from all forms of discrimination, violence and abuse- 183,000 older people – 60 per cent women – received humanitarian aid in 30 countries.- 45,404 people across nine countries took part in disaster preparedness work or training.- 5 national policies were introduced in Kenya, Kyrgyzstan and Tanzania to protect older people from violence and abuse.- 156 partners in 15 countries enabled almost 431,500 older people to access information about laws and support services relating to violence and abuse.4. My voice is heard- 254,000 people were mobilised to campaign for better policies and practice for older people in 30 countries.- 2,817 Older People’s Associations in 16 countries monitored the delivery of social pensions, health services and other entitlements.- 1.5 million older people in five countries adopted age-friendly policies and programmes in response to the Sustainable Development Goals and international humanitarian law. 5. Inclusion: Gender and Disability- Input from HAI at regional fora marking the anniversary of the Platform for Action led to older women’s issues and rights being included in the Asia Pacific and Africa Civil Society Reports and Regional Declarations on Beijing+25.- HAI promoted standards for sex, age and disability disaggregated data (SADDD) in programmes, for better analysis and evidence for strengthening gender and disability inclusion and also developed a new tool to ensure staff build gender into all advocacy work; new targets on gender analysis in advocacy; and the use of SADDD and gender analysis in funding proposals.- Inclusion training for HelpAge partners and international NGOs and donors on understanding and applying the Humanitarian Inclusion Standards was carried out in eight countries. Other example:HelpAge has developed an outcome tracking tool revealing a rise in the functional ability of those engaged in the programme (from two per cent in October 2018 to 48 per cent in March 2020), and a strengthening of independence and the ability to self-care (which rose from nine to 72 per cent over the same period). HelpAge also describes how the world by 2030 will have more older people than ever before and, for the first time in history, they will outnumber children under the age of 10. During the Covid-19 pandemic older people are hit the hardest of the pandemic and its consequences of economic hardship, lack of access to health care and isolation. The results by HelpAge related to Covid-19 are assessed within the frame of the agreement between Sida and HelpAge 2020-2024.
